Pore/Structural Features.Structure Type: Amorphous porous network of porphyrin rings; pores exhibit thermal contraction affecting sieving properties.

Guest Molecules.Mechanism: Adsorption by the polymer backbone; passes readily, with capacity increasing at lower temperatures.

Other Information.Additional Info: Not excluded by pore contraction at 91 K according to main selectivity claims and figures.

Guest Molecules.Mechanism: Size exclusion due to thermal contraction of pores below molecular kinetic diameter.

Other Information.Additional Info: Negligible uptake at 91 K. Pores are suggested to contract to between 3.46 and 3.64 Å, effectively excluding nitrogen. Nitrogen gas adsorption exhibited a peak at a critical temperature (between 110 K and 160 K) and decreased thereafter.

Sieving Mechanism: Molecular sieving based on temperature-dependent pore contraction.

Experimental Validation.Method: Gas adsorption/desorption isotherms (BELSORP Max), isosteric heat of adsorption (Clausius–Clapeyron plot), rate of adsorption (LDF model), cycling studies.
Experimental Validation.Performance Metrics: Contributes to overall O2:N2 selectivity up to 14.7 at 91 K through N2 exclusion. Isosteric heat of adsorption at zero loading: 17 kJ/mol for N2, 16 kJ/mol for O2. Oxygen adsorption rate constant: 0.16 s-1.

Other Information.Additional Info: Neat porphyrin polymer (without metal). Amorphous. Thermally stable up to 220 °C in oxygen atmosphere. Oxygen uptake is stable and reversible over repeated cycles.

Pore/Structural Features.Structure Type: Amorphous porous network of porphyrin rings; described as relatively rigid and open structure, especially when Fe(III) is present, inhibiting significant thermal contraction for sieving.

Guest Molecules.Mechanism: Adsorption onto metal sites and polymer backbone; capacity increases at lower temperatures.
Passes through pores with lower uptake compared to O2, especially at low temperatures.

Other Information.Additional Info: Very low selectivity over oxygen at 273 K. Nitrogen capacities were significantly lower than oxygen capacities at 91 K but not fully excluded. Did not exhibit the N2 adsorption peak observed for fb-POP and Co-POPs.

Sieving Mechanism: Limited molecular sieving primarily based on static pore size; oxygen adsorption enhanced by metal sites.

Experimental Validation.Method: Gas adsorption/desorption isotherms (BELSORP Max), rate of adsorption (LDF model).
Experimental Validation.Performance Metrics: O2:N2 selectivity: 1.04-1.09 at 273 K. Selectivity increase from 1.1 to 1.9 at 91 K. Oxygen adsorption rate constant: 0.17 s-1.

Other Information.Additional Info: Amorphous. Thermally stable up to 220 °C. Higher surface area and pore volume compared to cobalt samples. Fe(III) ions contributed to the formation of the polymer network.

Pore/Structural Features.Structure Type: Amorphous porous network of porphyrin rings.

Guest Molecules.Mechanism: Adsorption onto metal sites and polymer backbone; capacity increases at lower temperatures.
Passes through pores with lower uptake compared to O2, especially at low temperatures.

Other Information.Additional Info: Very low selectivity over oxygen at 273 K. Nitrogen capacities were significantly lower than oxygen capacities at 91 K but not fully excluded. Isobar suggests an N2 adsorption peak slightly below the studied temperature range (91–303 K).

Sieving Mechanism: Limited molecular sieving primarily based on static pore size; oxygen adsorption enhanced by metal sites.

Experimental Validation.Method: Gas adsorption/desorption isotherms (BELSORP Max), rate of adsorption (LDF model).
Experimental Validation.Performance Metrics: O2:N2 selectivity: 1.04-1.09 at 273 K. Selectivity increase from 1.1 to 1.9 at 91 K. Oxygen adsorption rate constant: 0.19 s-1.

Other Information.Additional Info: Amorphous. Thermally stable up to 220 °C. Lower surface area and pore volume compared to Fe(III) containing POPs. Forms a highly viscous gel during synthesis.

Pore/Structural Features.Structure Type: Amorphous porous network of porphyrin rings; described as relatively rigid and open pore structure due to presence of Fe(III) ions, inhibiting significant thermal contraction for sieving.

Guest Molecules.Mechanism: Adsorption onto metal sites and polymer backbone; capacity increases at lower temperatures.
Passes through pores with lower uptake compared to O2, especially at low temperatures.

Other Information.Additional Info: Very low selectivity over oxygen at 273 K. Nitrogen capacities were significantly lower than oxygen capacities at 91 K but not fully excluded. Did not exhibit the N2 adsorption peak observed for fb-POP and Co-POPs.

Sieving Mechanism: Limited molecular sieving primarily based on static pore size; oxygen adsorption enhanced by metal sites.

Experimental Validation.Method: Gas adsorption/desorption isotherms (BELSORP Max), rate of adsorption (LDF model).
Experimental Validation.Performance Metrics: O2:N2 selectivity: 1.04-1.09 at 273 K. Selectivity increase from 1.1 to 1.9 at 91 K. Oxygen adsorption rate constant: 0.19 s-1.

Other Information.Additional Info: Amorphous. Thermally stable up to 220 °C. Contains higher metal loading (Fe). Surface area and pore volume are intermediate between Fe-POP-O and Fe-POP-L, supporting Fe(III) contribution to structure. Forms a highly viscous gel during synthesis.

Pore/Structural Features.Structure Type: Amorphous porous network of porphyrin rings; pores exhibit thermal contraction affecting sieving properties.

Guest Molecules.Mechanism: Adsorption onto cobalt metal sites and polymer backbone; capacity increases at lower temperatures.
Size exclusion due to thermal contraction of pores below molecular kinetic diameter.

Other Information.Additional Info: Nitrogen capacities were significantly lower than oxygen capacities at 91 K. Nitrogen gas adsorption exhibited a peak at a critical temperature and decreased thereafter.

Sieving Mechanism: Molecular sieving based on temperature-dependent pore contraction and enhanced oxygen adsorption by cobalt sites.

Experimental Validation.Method: Gas adsorption/desorption isotherms (BELSORP Max), rate of adsorption (LDF model).
Experimental Validation.Performance Metrics: O2:N2 selectivity up to 1.3 at 273 K (for Co-POPs generally). O2:N2 selectivity up to 14.7 at 91 K (for Co-POPs generally). Oxygen adsorption rate constant: 0.24 s-1.

Other Information.Additional Info: Amorphous. Thermally stable up to 220 °C. Lower cobalt loading. Increase in oxygen gas capacity and selectivity with increased cobalt content suggests potential for improvement. Oxygen uptake is stable and reversible over repeated cycles.

Pore/Structural Features.Structure Type: Amorphous porous network of porphyrin rings; pores exhibit thermal contraction affecting sieving properties.

Guest Molecules.Mechanism: Adsorption onto cobalt metal sites and polymer backbone; initial uptake by cobalt ions in porphyrin rings.

Other Information.Additional Info: Increase in gas adsorption capacity at lower temperatures. Oxygen heat of adsorption: 20 kJ/mol (at zero loading). High oxygen loading (13 wt% at 1 atm).

Guest Molecules.Mechanism: Size exclusion due to thermal contraction of pores below molecular kinetic diameter.

Other Information.Additional Info: Nitrogen capacities were significantly lower than oxygen capacities at 91 K. Nitrogen gas adsorption exhibited a peak at a critical temperature and decreased thereafter. Isosteric heat of adsorption for N2: 17 kJ/mol (at zero loading).

Sieving Mechanism: Molecular sieving based on temperature-dependent pore contraction and strong oxygen adsorption by cobalt sites.

Experimental Validation.Method: Gas adsorption/desorption isotherms (BELSORP Max), isosteric heat of adsorption (Clausius–Clapeyron plot), cycling studies.
Experimental Validation.Performance Metrics: Extraordinary O2:N2 selectivity of up to 14.7 at 91 K. Oxygen loading: 13 wt% at 1 atm. Isosteric heat of adsorption for O2: 20 kJ/mol, for N2: 17 kJ/mol (at zero loading). Stable and reversible oxygen uptake over 6 cycles.

Other Information.Additional Info: Amorphous. Thermally stable up to 220 °C. Higher cobalt loading (0.44 wt% Co). Potential for use in hybrid adsorption–cryogenic air separation systems. Oxygen uptake is stable and reversible over repeated cycles.
